Super Bowl champion tackle Michael Oher publicly discussed his court case against the Tuohy family for the first time in an interview with The New York Times for an article published Sunday. Sean and Leigh Anne Tuohy had a conservatorship over Oher from high school throughout his eight-year NFL career. In 2009, the same year Oher was drafted to the Baltimore Ravens, Warner Bros. released â€œThe Blind Side,â€ a movie depicting the relationship between Oher and the Tuohy family. Sandra Bullock and Tim McGraw starred in the film as Leigh Anne and Sean, respectively, grossing just under $310 million at the box office. â€œItâ€™s hard to describe my reaction,â€ Oher said, recalling his first time watching the film when speaking with The New York Times. â€œIt seemed kind of funny to me, to tell you the truth, like it was a comedy about someone else. It didnâ€™t register. But as social media was just starting to grow, and I started seeing stuff that Iâ€™m dumb. Every article mentioned â€˜The Blind Side,â€™ like it was part of my name. â€œIf my kids canâ€™t do something in class, will their teacher think, â€˜Their dad is dumb â€” is that why theyâ€™re not getting it?'â€ The film was based on Michael Lewisâ€™ 2006 book on Oher and the Tuohy family. Prior to the release of the movie, Oher felt Lewisâ€™ book also made him seem uneducated, which Oher felt affected his draft status. Oher was selected with the No. 23 pick in the 2009 NFL Draft. â€œThe NFL people were wondering if I could read a playbook,â€ Oher said. Oher eventually went on to have a successful career in the NFL and won Super Bowl XLVII in 2013 when the Ravens defeated the San Francisco 49ers. In Oherâ€™s lawsuit against the Tuohys, his lawyers allege the Tuohys exploited him by using his name, image and likeness to promote speaking engagements that paid them roughly $8 million over the last 20 years â€” and by repeatedly saying they adopted him. In August 2023, Oher issued a 14-page petition alleging the Tuohys lied about adopting him when they presented him with paperwork to make them his conservators months after he turned 18. The petition also alleges the Tuohys negotiated a deal with Twentieth Century Fox that secured them and their two birth children $225,000 each, plus 2.5 percent of â€œdefined net proceedsâ€ from â€œThe Blind Side.â€ The petition said a separate contract purportedly signed by Oher in 2007 â€œappears to give away to Fox, without any payment whatsoeverâ€ the life rights to his story. Oher says he has no memory of signing such a document, according to the filing. A Tennessee judge ended the unusual conservatorship last year, but did not dismiss the financial part of the case. In filings, the Tuohys have said they paid Oher the same share of â€œThe Blind Sideâ€ film profits â€” about $138,000 â€” that each of them, as well as their two children, received. The lawyers of the Tuohy family state they have a right to tell the story of their family, which includes Oher. Oherâ€™s lawyers say without him, the Tuohy family wouldnâ€™t have a profitable story to tell. The Tuohys have filed for a partial summary judgement scheduled for Oct. 1. The case likely wonâ€™t reach trial until 2025, if it does at all. HENDERSON, Nev. â€” Gardner Minshew will be the Las Vegas Raidersâ€™ starting quarterback in Week 1 of the 2024 season, coach Antonio Pierce announced Sunday. The Raiders signed Minshew this offseason to compete for the job with Aidan Oâ€™Connell, who started 10 games last year as a rookie. Pierce said earlier last week that the Raiders would make a decision after their preseason game against the Dallas Cowboys on Saturday and, after meeting with general manager Tom Telesco and offensive coordinator Luke Getsy, he tabbed Minshew as the winner of the position battle. â€œA lot of things went into it. It wasnâ€™t based off of last night,â€ Pierce said Sunday. â€œWe feel like Gardner gives us the best opportunity to get off to a fast start, and thatâ€™s who weâ€™re going with. We support him. Our teamâ€™s behind it. Our staffâ€™s behind. Our organizationâ€™s behind it.â€ GO DEEPERMinshew Mania hits Vegas: Can the NFL journeyman be the Raiders' answer at QB? Minshew started against the Cowboys and did not fare well. He played five drives and completed just 10 of 21 passes for 95 yards. Oâ€™Connell looked better than Minshew in four drives of action. He completed 14 of 20 passes for 96 yards and one touchdown, but he ended on a sour note as he threw a pick six on his final pass of the game. Oâ€™Connell said of the interception that he â€œstared it down.â€ â€œIt sucks. That one will linger.â€ Pierce said Minshew had the upper hand when it came to experience, running the offense properly and his ability to process information. For him to hold onto the job, though, heâ€™ll have to make significant strides. He has struggled to find consistency going back to OTAs, and that showed up against the Cowboys on Saturday. Far too many of his throws were either poorly timed or completely off target, which led to several missed opportunities for the offense to extend drives or put up points. If that continues into the season, Oâ€™Connell could have an opportunity to take the starting job back. â€œThereâ€™s a lot of stuff we can get better at,â€ Pierce said. â€œI donâ€™t think anything here is a finished product. But, based off of where we want to go in the first quarter of the season, we feel like Gardner gives us the best opportunity.â€ Pierce said Oâ€™Connell handled the news that he lost the quarterback competition well. He also left the door open for both quarterbacks to end up playing at some point this fall. â€œThose two gentlemen are professionals,â€ Pierce said. â€œThe way theyâ€™ve handled this competition has really resonated throughout our building, especially our staff and our team. Theyâ€™ve cheered each other on. Theyâ€™ve been good teammates. Theyâ€™ve brought out the best version of each other in practices and in the games. They both took it on the chin like a champ. â€œI told them to just both be ready,â€ Pierce continued. â€œIn the National Football League, you never know. But Aidan is a younger player that has tremendous upside. I think heâ€™ll still be a starter at some point in this league, whether itâ€™s this year or next year. He will play in games. Gardnerâ€™s done a good job of being that older presence. â€¦ Heâ€™s been through some adversity, so thatâ€™s been good for Aidan.â€ GO DEEPERReed: Aidan O'Connell should be the Raiders' starter, but the outlook at QB is concerning Ultimately, the Raiders believe Minshew gives them the best chance to succeed early in the season. â€œHis personality is infectious, his energy is infectious and his leadership is infectious,â€ Pierce said. â€œFootwork in the pocket. Staying on script. There is some magic about him when he does break the pocket and does his thing, but thereâ€™s a lot of times where the first or second read is there and weâ€™ve got to let it rip. He understands that. And, more importantly, (he has to focus on) taking care of the football.â€ Raiders safety Marcus Epps, who played with Minshew for two seasons with the Philadelphia Eagles, shared that sentiment. â€œHe is just a gamer,â€ Epps said. â€œ(Heâ€™s a) very smart player who cares a lot and works really hard, and he is going to give you everything heâ€™s got every play. Definitely a guy you want in your corner.â€ Required reading Raiders training camp: Maxx Crosby gets into skirmish, Davante Adams misses practice Aidan Oâ€™Connell, Gardner Minshew play well in Raidersâ€™ preseason loss to Vikings Davante Adams, Raiders offense shows progress in open practice at Allegiant Stadium (Photo: Chris Unger / Getty Images)

CHARLOTTE, N.C. â€” Dave Canales put his commitment to the running game on display at the end of Saturdayâ€™s exhibition against the New York Jets, when fifth-team running back Dillon Johnson ran the ball on every play of the Carolina Panthersâ€™ final, seven-play drive. On his seventh rush, Johnson banged his way into the end zone for a 2-yard touchdown as time expired in the Jetsâ€™ 15-12 victory. It was the Panthersâ€™ first touchdown of the preseason â€” and first overall since the fourth quarter of a Christmas Eve loss to Green Bay last year. But the most important run of the night came at halftime, when running back Chuba Hubbard jogged across the field at Bank of America Stadium toward the locker room with no sign of a limp or any other issue. When last we saw Hubbard, he was grabbing his knee after an awkward slip that preceded a big hit by Jets safety Chuck Clark during the teamsâ€™ joint practice. In fact, Hubbard said he could have finished out the session against the Jets if the training staff had let him. The former Oklahoma State standout has played 49 of a possible 51 games since the Panthers drafted him in the fourth round in 2021. But after he went down Thursday on a play that drew a flag on Clark, a number of Hubbardâ€™s offensive teammates came to his defense â€” and nearly came to blows with the Jets. â€œJust kind of planted weird, got hit, bent my knee back a little awkwardly,â€ he said. â€œBut other than that, it really wasnâ€™t anything too crazy.â€ Hubbard had no hard feelings for Clark, who dapped him up at the end of practice. â€œThatâ€™s football,â€ he said. â€œSometimes youâ€™re gonna take a few licks, get back up, deal it back.â€ Hubbard is coming off a breakout season in which he rushed for more than 900 yards and finished in the top five in the NFL in catch percentage. He entered training camp as the clear starter in a running back room that includes veteran Miles Sanders and Mike Boone and return specialist Raheem Blackshear. So the Canadian-born Hubbard is a key cog in Canalesâ€™ plan to establish the running game. And he liked how the offense functioned against the Jets on Thursday, when starters had as many as 50-60 snaps. â€œIt was a great day. We started to see glimpses of who weâ€™re gonna be and kind of putting it all together (during) different periods,â€ Hubbard said. â€œObviously it felt good all being on the same track.â€ Itâ€™s unclear whether Hubbard and the offense will get a chance to put things together in a preseason game. Canales was noncommittal on whether the starters would play in the exhibition finale next weekend at Buffalo. Hubbard doesnâ€™t have a strong feeling one way or the other. â€œThe game obviously, you kind of get a different feel of actual tackling,â€ he said. â€œBut whatever coach wants, Iâ€™m good with it.â€ Required reading Ten things from Panthers-Jets: Robert Huntâ€™s a dawg, and a need for Stephon Gilmore? KANSAS CITY, Mo. â€” While the fans at Arrowhead Stadium roared, producing a collective sound of amazement, Patrick Mahomes simply jogged back to the huddle as if he hadnâ€™t just pulled off one of his greatest tricks. Unlike most of his best highlights, Mahomes wasnâ€™t as thrilled by what he accomplished as everyone watching him, whether from the stands or on national TV, during the Kansas City Chiefsâ€™ preseason game Saturday afternoon against the Detroit Lions. Less than two weeks after executing his trick in practice, the Chiefs quarterback threw and completed his first behind-the-back pass in a game during the opening quarter. Mahomes, who is known for his creative playstyle and rare arm strength, explained after the game that he was forced by his favorite teammate, tight end Travis Kelce, to use his improvisational skills. On a third-and-3 snap in Lions territory, Mahomes executed a play-action fake to fullback Carson Steele for a run-pass option play. However, Kelce, the primary pass catcher on the play, didnâ€™t run the route designed for him. â€œI didnâ€™t do it to look cool,â€ Mahomes said, smiling. â€œI literally did it as I was, like, pissed. He was supposed to run a flat route. â€¦ Iâ€™m yelling at him and then he doesnâ€™t run it. So out of spite, I threw a behind-the-back pass, but now itâ€™s gonna be a highlight.â€ One reason Kelce didnâ€™t run his intended route, and out route into the flat, was because edge rusher Josh Paschal engaged him near the line of scrimmage. Once Kelce realized Paschal pushed him in the opposite direction, he stopped and turned around in the middle of the field. â€œWe had the leverage we wanted,â€ Mahomes said. â€œI shouldâ€™ve known because (Kelce) asked me what (route) he had as he was motioning over. You can kind of see him look back at me. But I thought I told him and it was going to be open, so I pulled (the ball after the play-action fake) and then he wasnâ€™t out there, so I was going to run for it. â€œOf course, he was blocking and then he just turned around and I threw it to him.â€ After pushing Kelce, Paschal began chasing Mahomes. By rolling to his right and swinging his right arm around his back, Mahomes created the ideal angle for the behind-the-back pass. Kelce caught the ball and ran for an 8-yard gain. He celebrated during the fansâ€™ ovation by standing up and pointing at Mahomes. This son of a gun actually did it!! Magic Mahomes â€” Jason Kelce (@JasonKelce) August 17, 2024 Later in the game â€” which ended in a 24-23 win for the Lions â€” Kelce shared his perspective while on the Chiefsâ€™ sideline during a short interview on the NFL Network broadcast, joking that he wasnâ€™t at fault. â€œYou know heâ€™s got the voice thing,â€ Kelce said, ribbing Mahomes and imitating his distinctive voice. â€œHe kind of mumbled out the play and I couldnâ€™t hear it. I was walking up to the line and I was trying to decipher what he was saying. Before I knew it, he snapped the ball and then I kind of saw him out of my peripheral run to the sideline, so I was trying to go help my guy out. â€œBy the time I looked over there, he was already in mid-form, like a photo on a sports card, throwing the ball to me, so I guess right place at the right time.â€ GO DEEPERUndrafted rookie Carson Steele never played fullback in college. Now he could make the Chiefs Throughout his 12-year career, Kelce has often executed daring things that most tight ends or receivers cannot. He can recognize the opposing defenseâ€™s coverage, alter his route â€” oftentimes deciding to run a completely different route in the middle of the play â€” and still be available and in rhythm with Mahomes before the ball is passed to him. One of Kelceâ€™s touchdowns last season came because he improvised his route. Near the goal line, the Chiefs started their third-and-goal play against the Chicago Bears with Kelce in a bunch formation next to tight end Noah Gray and receiver Marquez Valdes-Scantling. When Kelce heard the play call from Mahomes, his assignment was to run a corner route to the back pylon. But just before the ball was snapped, Kelce anticipated and visualized himself ending the play in the back of the end zone near the goal post. The Bears were in zone coverage, matching Kelce with safety Elijah Hicks. Kelce started his route running directly at Hicks, making the defender commit to covering the perimeter of the end zone. But after planting his right foot, Kelce ran a corner-post route, double move to create plenty of space for him to get open for a 3-yard touchdown reception. Who do you believe? Coach Andy Reidâ€™s response to the highlight was a simple one: He was just glad Mahomesâ€™ behind-the-back pass ended as a completion. â€œI heard he blamed it on Kelce, but thatâ€™s all right,â€ Reid said. â€œ(Mahomes) does it in practice, so Iâ€™m all right with it as long as itâ€™s a completion. They do it in basketball (almost) every game, so itâ€™s not that big of a deal.â€ But in NFL history, there appears to be no video of a quarterback even attempting a behind-the-back pass in a regular-season game. One of the reasons Mahomes attempted the behind-the-back pass was because the Chiefsâ€™ defense blitzed. He caught the ball, spun to his right and ran untouched to the end zone. â€œIt was cool that I completed it,â€ Mahomes said after Thursdayâ€™s practice. â€œYou want to get it in a live-type of atmosphere â€” and thatâ€™s as live as youâ€™re going to get in practice.â€ GO DEEPERChiefs 53-man roster projection: Questions remain at running back, cornerback Mahomes first started experimenting with a behind-the-back pass during the 2018 season, when he attempted the feat in practices closed to fans and during team periods that were not observed by reporters. â€œThe first thing he said was, â€˜Iâ€™ve been telling you to do that for a while; thatâ€™s one of the plays Iâ€™ve been telling you that you can do it,'â€ Mahomes said Thursday of Reidâ€™s reaction. â€œHeâ€™s all for it. Itâ€™s me whoâ€™s the one thatâ€™s hesitant to do it in a game.â€ After successful execution of his trick in a game, Mahomes knows he might be in a similar situation when he can use his unorthodox throwing motion â€” especially if the play involves improvising with Kelce â€” in the regular season, perhaps as early as the season opener on Sept. 5 against the Baltimore Ravens. â€œI always told you that if itâ€™s going to happen, itâ€™s going to have to happen naturally,â€ Mahomes said after Saturdayâ€™s game. â€œI canâ€™t force it. It probably looked pretty cool. Itâ€™s not something I want to try to major in. â€œIt might be something that just kind of happens every once in a while.â€ GO DEEPERHow Louis Rees-Zammit is tackling the transition from rugby to the NFL with the Chiefs Chiefsâ€™ top rookies excel Receiver Xavier Worthy and left tackle Kingsley Suamataia, the Chiefsâ€™ top two rookies, had encouraging performances in the first half Saturday.
